div.head: Circa textum
div.p:
Desiring something from want Lombardus, Sent. I, prol., (I, 3, ll. 1).
etc. This is the prologue to the book of Sentences which is a book divided into a prologue and a treatise. The latter begins at,
of the old and new law Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 1, c. 1, (I, 55, ll. 5). .

The first part is divided into four principle parts. In the first part, the author's reason for aggregating is stated. In the second part, a reproof of the enemies in opposition is stated. In the third part, the commendation of the work in what follows is stated. In the fourth part, the inciting of the hearer for finishing the book is stated. The second part begins at,
quamvis non ambigamus Lombardus, Sent. I, prol. (I, 3, ll. 16). . The third part begins at,
therefore of those things hateful, the church Lombardus, Sent. I, prol. (I, 4, ll. 11). . The fourth part begins at,
therefore this labor ought not Lombardus, Sent. I, prol. (I, 4, ll. 21). . etc.

The first part is able to be divided into three parts according to which the Master posits three causes detracting him from the compilation of this work. The first is the subtlety of the science itself. The second is the difficulty of the material. The third is the sting of envy. In the second part he puts three causes urging and inducing him to the compilation of this book. The first is the example of the poor widow. The second is the hope of an eternal reward. The third is the constant request of his companions. In the third part he compares the aforesaid causes to one another by showing the victory of the motivating causes. The second part begins at,
consummationis fiduciam
Lombardus, Sent. I, prol., (I, 3, ll. 4).
. The third part beings at
quae vincit zelus Lombardus, Sent. I, prol., (I, 3, ll. 8). . Any of the other causes are able to be divided, but this division suffices for now. And this last cause is divided into three. For in the first part, the evidence of the opposition of the enemies is stated. In the second, the reason for the opposition is stated. In the third, the wickedness of those opposing is stated. The second part begins at,
quia dissentientibus voluntatum motibus
Lombardus, Sent. I, prol. (I, 3, ll. 17-18).
. The third part begins at,
qui non rationi subiciunt
Lombardus, Sent. I, prol. (I, 3, ll. 22-23).
.

Then the second principle part follows,
quamvis non ambigamus Lombardus, Sent. I, prol. (I, 3, ll. 16). , in which the double refutation of the detractors is stated. The first is the about the attack on truth. The second is about the teaching of falsehoods. The second part begins at,
quorum professio Lombardus, Sent. I, prol. (xxxx).

The third principle part follows,
horum igitur Lombardus, Sent. I, prol. (I, 4, ll. 11).
etc., in which the commendation of the work to follow is stated. And he does four things here since in the first place he identifies the work of the final cause, in the second place of the efficient cause, in the third place of the material cause, and in the fourth place of the formal cause. The second part begins at,
cum labore Lombardus, Sent. I, prol. (I, 4, ll. 13). .
The third part begins at,
ex testimoniis veritatis Lombardus, Sent. I, prol. (I, 4, ll. 14). . The fourth part begins at,
in quo haereticae doctrinae Lombardus, Sent. I, prol. (I, 4, ll. 17). Text reads: "...vipereae doctrinae fraudulentiam prodidimus...". .

Then the fourth and last principle part follows,
non ergo debet hic labor Lombardus, Sent. I, prol. (I, 4, ll. 21). , which is divided into three according to a threefold schema for inciting the hearer to complete the book. For in the first place the hearer is enticed by the useful brevity, second by the humble truth, third by the exposure of falsity. The second part begins at,
in hoc autem tractatu Lombardus, Sent. I, prol. (I, 4, ll. 26). . The third part at,
ut autem quod quaeritur Lombardus, Sent. I, prol. (I, 4, ll. 29). . This is the division of the prologue in general.

But the Master proceeds more specifically since he first puts one cause moving him to the compilation of this book which is the desire of completing it and immediately he adds the cause drawing him away from it, which is the lack of talent and knowledge. After these things, he identifies a cause drawing him away which is the loftiness of the subject matter and the magnitude of the labor, and immediately he includes the contrary moving cause which is the confidence of divine help and the prize promised by Christ. After these things, he points out the victory of the moving causes by saying that the intense love which he has for the church, which inflames him to compile this work, conquers the two things which seem to draw him away from the compilation of it.

In another part, he says that he turns his attention to three things. First regarding the defense of the catholic faith, second regarding the truth of theological explanation, third regarding the manifestation of the sacraments. After these things, he puts another moving which is the love and presence of brothers and colleagues, and immediately he adds a third contrary cause drawing him away which is the sting and contradiction of critics . After this he puts the cause of contradiction which is the discord and disorderedness of the will from which error comes and from error hate and from hate arises contradiction. After this he points out the wickedness of the ones contradicting since, namely, they do not subject the will to reason and they do not follow the right reason nor do they wish to submit themselves to the authority of sacred scripture. Rather to both reason and the authority of scripture they propose their own sense and by some superstitious religion externally simulated they have an argument for showing a new wisdom, by devising some doctrine and by some loud intention fighting stubbornly against the truth. After this he assigns the causes of the work. In the first place he touches the final cause which is twofold, namely the turning of the church from falsity or evil things and the manifestation of catholic truth. After this he puts the efficient cause which is twofold, namely the principle cause which is God and the instrumental cause which is the Magister himself. After he puts the material cause, namely the testimony of truth of the canons and saints. After this, he touches the formal cause which is twofold, namely the form of the treatise which consists in a division of the work through books and chapters; the other is the form of treating, which is the same as the mode of acting. After this he says that in each book he puts forward chapters for an easier and lighter entrance or introduction. And thus the sentences of this prologue end here, about which the following question is asked.

div.head: Rationes principales
div.p: Whether a pilgrim is able to assent scientifically without a special gift to every theological truth even a supernatural truth?

That this is so in the first place because every natural potency is able to perform its own natural act, but the intellect is a natural potency and its own operation is to know and to understand, therefore it is able to assent naturally to these truths without faith or the infusion of another light. This is confirmed because one is able to assent by the dictate of reason alone, otherwise they would truly be able to assent to anything. The antecedent is true and the consequence is proved on the one hand because in the first place the the senses are likewise able to have knowledge of that which is sensible, and on the other hand in the second place because all things truly have a single (ratio) of acting on the intellect, therefore all things are likewise in the first place are able to be known.

In the second place, heretics, the damned, and the devil are able to assent to the theological
truth with a special light, therefore also the pilgrim. The antecedent is clear from the rich man of
Luke 16 Cf. Luke 16:19-31 . Then in the second place because when the agent and patient are sufficiently applied, there will follow an equal action. But the
agent intellect is able to make all things and the possible intellect is able to become all things
Aristoteles, De anima, III. 5 (430a14-15)
as is clear from I De anima. Therefore in a man having prepared (approximatis) equally, the action follows in him.

In the third place, if the question turned out to be false, it would follows that some a light or special gift would be infused to some theologian. The consequent is false because no modern theologian perceives himself to be so infused. The consequence is clear because it would be impossible that such lights or such habits are possessed by are hidden to the one having them as is argued by
Thomas Argentinae in the first article of the second question of his prologue Thomas de Argentina, I, prologus, q. 2, a. 1 At we present we are not able to find a direct parallel in the identified passage. .

In the fourth place the pilgrim is able to convinced that there is a future life after this life by the command of reason alone, therefore. The consequence holds since this is a theological truth. The antecedent is true because just as the pursuit of a stone is to find a final place of rest, so it is with human beings. But the pursuit of a stone, which is found when these ends are acquired , is not able not to rest, therefore it is also the case for the pilgrim. The minor is clear. The major is proved because human beings are not less ordered to their natural end than a stone. Thus it is further true that the pursuit of man to naturally and finally rest in something, when this or these things are acquired, is not able not to rest. But there is not such thing in the present life, therefore there remains another life for the where human beings can rest. The major is clear through what has already been said, and the minor is clear from itself and through what
Augustine says in the first book of the Confessions, chapter 1 ,
Lord you have made us for yourself and our heart is restless until it rests in you. Augustinus, Confessiones I, 1, 1 (CCSL 27, 1, ll. 6-7).

On the contrary
Augustine in his Commentary on Genesis
says
The authority of scripture is greater than perspicacity of any human talent Augustinus, XXX . Again
Lombard, in his prologue
says
ardua scandere, opus ultra vires praesumpsimus agere
Lombardus, Sent. I, prol. (I, 3, ll. 3-4).
. Again,
Augustine in his second book on the Lord's sermon on the mount
cum rationalis anima cogitat ac ratiocinatur quidquid in ea ratione, verum est non est ei attribuendum sed ipsi luci veritatis
Augustinus, De sermone Domini in monte II.32 (CCSL 35, 122, ll. 705-708). . Again no one is able to acquire created wisdom unless they have been illuminated with the grace which is God, therefore. The consequence is clear, and the antecedent is from
Augustine 83 quaestiones, question 24
Augustinus, De diversis quaestionibus octoginta tribus, q.24 (CCSL 44A, 29-20). .

div.head: First Conclusion
div.p: First conclusion: though theological assent is not distinct from a theological proposition, nevertheless it is true that two propositions are formed of the same subject or predicate signifying the same thing and are distinguished one from the other specifically. The first part is clear because, if they were distinguished, it would follow that theological assent would be able to be without a theological proposition. The consequent is false because then someone would be able to assent without complex knowledge which is contrary to the truth. The second part is proved because, if it were supposed that a believing person formed the following proposition Christ has died and an unbelieving person formed the same proposition with respect to the terms, then the faithful person assents to what is signified by this proposition when forming it, and the unfaithful person does not assent, therefore they are specifically distinct. The consequence is clear because one is really and intrinsically assent and the other is not, and nevertheless they have the same subject and predicate. Therefore the conclusion is true.

The first corollary: it is true that a person could know the entire holy scriptures and not be a theologian. This is clear because if an unbelieving person knew the scriptures, he would not be a theologian because he would not assent. This is confirmed because if the believing pilgrim knew and formed every proposition to which the unbeliever assented, he would despite this still be an infidel because he would consent to them. There for similar reason, the one know the Holy Scriptures and dissenting is not a theology. For this reason it should be known that infidelity is an assent with respect to what is false or dissent with respect to what is determined to be true by the Church or revealed in Holy Scripture.

The second corollary: it is true that the pilgrim could be informed with the theological habit yet not be considered a theologian. From this is able to further inferred and conceded that from the ordained law
the theologian is able to remain in faith, but is not always able t to remain or be a theologian without faith. From this it further follows that the theological part is not as essential to the theological habit as the habit.

The third corollary: one indistinct proposition is able to have two contradictories distinct in species. This is clear because the contradictory of a proposition is able to be assent in the mind of one and dissent in the mind of another.

div.head: Second conclusion
div.p: The second conclusion: though a theological proposition is theological cognition, nevertheless it is not necessarily knowledge by which someone is said to know the total object of its own being. The first part is proved because faith or theological knowledge do not differ from theological assent, but theological assent is a theological proposition, therefore a theological proposition is theological knowledge or cognition. The major premise is clear because theological faith is not able to be without theological assent, otherwise someone would believe something and not assent to it, which is false. The minor is clear from the first conclusion. The second part is proved because nothing is caused by itself, but our knowledge is at least partially caused by an object, therefore this knowledge is not its own total object. This is confirmed because, suppose there was a vision that was a vision of itself, it would still be required some object by which ti is caused. Thus having supposed that the same thing is knowledge of itself, nevertheless another object is required by which such knowledge is caused, and, as a consequence, it is not its total object, which was the conclusion to be proved.
First corollary: theological propositions are not the object of Holy Scripture.

Second corollary: theology or another science is not properly speaking known, but is that by which something is known or cognized. This is clear through the fact that that which is known is the object of the science, but science is not the object of itself, at least not the the total object, therefore.

The third corollary: the following proposition according to the force of the word is false: Socrates knows grammar, logic, theology or any other science. This is clear from the fundamental point since science is not properly known but is that by which something is known to be in this way or not.

div.head: Third conclusion
div.p:
The third conclusion, though it is not impossible for the pilgrim to not believe any theological truths and still have the act and habit of faith, nevertheless under the present law it is impossible that the pilgrim assent to theological truths without any special light. The first part is proved in the first place regarding the habit. There is no doubt that many have the habit of the virtues without that habit being put into act. But that the act of faith is able to be without believing is proved because the act of faith and the actuation or the doing itself are not more identical than an accident and its adherence. But God is able to make an accident without adherence, therefore. The second part is proved through Augustine in some epistle, where he says:
Neque enim cum coepero te in tanti huius secreti intelligentiam introducere (nisi Deus intus ad iuverit, non potero) PL 33:453 , and elsewhere in several places. Again Anselm I Cur Deus Homo, in chapter two:
Rectus ordo exigit ut profunda Christianae fidei, prius credamus, quam ea ratione fidei praesumamus discutere
Anselmus, Cur Deus Homo I, c. 1 (II, 48, ll. 16-17)
. Again Augustine in in his first homily on John dicens,
Deus illuminat parvulos et indoctos lumine fidei, maiores autem lumine sapientiae Augustinus, xxx
Therefore a special light is required in order to scientificaly assent to theological truths.

The first corollary: many are saved in the end who have never believed or never actually believe. This is clear when considering young children who die immediately after baptism. Again this is clear when considering those being baptized how are lacking the use of reason, like those who are born mentally impaired.

The second corollary: many are blessed in the kingdom of heaven who, if they had believed, would have been damned and would have been among the numbers of the reprobate or in the place of the damned. This is clear from considering the young children of the Greeks dying immediately
after baptism before the age of discretion. For it happens that the Greeks are baptized, though it is through a different form of words, and as a consequence they receive the grace by which they are able to be saved. Nevertheless because the adult Greeks believe differently than the Roman Church believes and commands people to believe, therefore they are not in the state of being saved.

The third corollary: it is possible under the current law that the pilgrim does not believe just as the church commands them to believe, and nevertheless the pilgrim while believing in this manner in no way sins or is at fault of. Or it is possible that some pilgrim is deficient in believing while not culpable and nevertheless does not believe in the way the church commands that they should believe. This is clear because it is possible that someone can licitly believe nothing for a certain amount of time, therefore it is possible that such a person does not err nor believe just as the Roman Church believes. From what has been said, it is clear that the negative part of the question true.

div.head: Objections and responses
div.p: Against the first conclusion it is first argued in the following way: a theological proposition is able to exist without theological assent, therefore it is distinguished. The consequence is valid. The antecedent is proved because every proposition which a believer is able to form is able to be formed by an unbeliever while remaining in a state of unbelief. And since this unbeliever does not have the assent of a theological truth, it follows that the theological proposition formed by this person is not intrinsically assent.

In the second place it follows that if a theologian were to become an infidel or heretic, then he would lose the entirety of the theological science. The consequence is clear because he would lose the assent to the theological propositions and such assent is the theological science. But the falsity of this is proved since such a person would still know how to defend our faith,to read and dispute, and to solve arguments just as before, since he does not know less than before.

In the third place, we assent to a proposition through assent, therefore theological assent is not a theological proposition. The consequence is clear because we do not assent to a proposition by means of a proposition since, if this were the case, the same thing would be that by which we assent and that to which we assent.

In the fourth place, it is possible that a proposition exists and assent to the proposition does not exist, therefore. The antecedent is proved because a person is able to believe some proposition to be true and later not believe, but rather believe the opposite on account of some reasons, while the same proposition remains.

In the fifth place against the second part it is argued because, if assent distinguished the type (species) of the proposition, then if someone were to form the following proposition no man is an ass, then it would follows that no one dissenting to this would be able to form a proposition of the same type (species). The consequence is clear from the terms. The falsity is proved because the one dissenting to this proposition is able to form a proposition of the same subject and predicate, therefore it is of the same type (species). This consequence is clear since propositions are nothing other than their terms taken together.

In the sixth place against the corollary because either faith and theology are the same habit or not. If they are the same, then the one having the theological habit has faith and as a consequence is a theologian. If they are diverse, then suppose that there is a remission of all things uniformly, equally, and precisely toward non-being, then they either arrive equally at non-being or not. If the first, then they are equal and consequently theology is not superior to faith which is false and against what
Augustine XIV De Trinitate in chapter one
says,
hac scientia, scilicet theologia, non pollent plurimi quamvis fide polleant Augustinus, De Trinitate, XIV, c. 1, xxx . If the second, then it follows that theology will stand without faith which is opposed what has been said.

In the seventh place against the second part of the second conclusion: everything that is known is true, but only a proposition is true, therefore only a proposition is known, therefore only a proposition is the total object of our science.

In the eighth place against the corollary of the same conclusion because either the total object of theology is a theological proposition or an external thing or the thing signified by the proposition. If the first, then the objection against the first corollary is sustained. The second option is not valid because then there would be several sciences about contingent things being able
to be disposed differently just as the sciences about objects, which is opposed to what the
Philosopher says in book VI of Ethics Aristoteles, Ethica, VI, xxx
and in
book I of the Posterior Analytics Aristoteles, Posteriora Analytica . The third option is not valid for the same reason since the proposition signifies a thing outside the soul. This is confirmed because by the same reasons some external thing would be the object of an opinion, of faith, and of error, and as a consequence it would mean that one and the same person would know, opine, believe and be ignorant which are false. The consequence is clear for it is true that a person knows that God is three and one, opines that He alone moves the heavens, believes that He became incarnate, and errs when thinking that He is of finite strength.

In the ninth place against the third conclusion: theological truths are either self-evident or deduced from what is self-evident, therefore for the knowledge of such things faith is not necessary. The antecedent is proved because no one would be obliged to believe without any doubt something that is self-evident in and of itself or deduced from something self-evident, but one is obliged to believe the theological truths without any doubt, therefore. The major premise is clear because every true thing is deduced or deducible from a first principle since every true thing is virtually contained within it.

In the tenth place, if it were true that such a light, etc, it would follow that anyone would be able to have greater certitude about such truths than the certitude of science. The consequent is false but the consequence is clear because the certitude of faith is infinite since it is infinitely removed from every degree of doubt.

In the eleventh place, no special light is required in order to assent to a lie, therefore it is not otherwise for a theological truth since the one saying a theological truth, which he believes to be false, speaks a lie.

div.head: Responses
div.p: In response to these arguments, to the first argument I say that a theological proposition is able to be taken in two ways. In one mode for some proposition signifying a theological thing, and thus a pure vocal proposition is able to be called theological. In another mode it is taken from a proposition which is intrinsically theological assent, and thus I say that such a proposition, which is the sign of the signified theological thing, is not able to be without theological assent. And for the proof, what the argument assumes is denied when taking the theological proposition in the second mode, though it is possible to form any proposition signifying whatever one wants.

To the second argument, the consequent is conceded when taking science as something that includes theological assent. But when taking science as a habit by which one is able to know how to conclude one proposition from another, in such a case he would not lose the science, but nevertheless such a person ought not to be called a theologian

To the third argument, the antecedent is denied, and for the proof it is said that the assent is the proposition itself by which we assent not to the proposition but that reality is thus or is not thus.

To the fourth argument, the antecedent is denied, and for the proof I say that as long as this proposition and assent will remain so also will a similar proposition be able to remain which will not be assent, and then this proposition is not a theological proposition, and thus it is able to be said that this proposition will remain, but will not remain a proposition.

To the fifth argument the consequent is conceded and for its proof the antecedent is conceded but the consequence is denied because the proposition which is an assent beyond the terms includes another assent, namely an assent which is not included in the other. In the second place it is able to be said that the copula of one is not of the same type as the copula of the other because the mode of joining the subject and the predicate is diverse since one proposition is assent while other is not, but only apprehension.

To the sixth argument it is said that they are not one habit. And since it is posited that they remit uniformly, perhaps someone would say that they are not able to remit uniformly. But having admitted the case, it is said that some degree of theology will remain, but it would not properly be called theology because without faith the habit would not be sufficient such that the one having could be said to have a theological habit. And thus it is able to be said in
conformity with what has been said above that theology is able to remain without faith, but one is not able to remain in theology without faith, for this habit would not be sufficient such that the one having it could be said to be to have the theological habit, at least according to to present world order (law). Note that Alphonsus holds that the habit of faith and theology is the same, in the third question of his prologue, article two, conclusion one, but Thomas Argentinae holds the opposite and solves his arguments in
question four, article two Thomas de Argentina, I, q. 4, a. 2 .

To the seventh argument, which is against the second conclusion, the minor is denied because many things are true which are not propositions like the things signified by the propositions. And this appears to be the mind of
Aristotle in his book on the Categories in the chapter on opposites Aristoteles, Praedicamentorum, xxx , where he says that the thing signified by one contradictory proposition contradicts the thing signified by the other propositions, and if one is true, the other is false. But the things signified by some extrinsic denomination assert (dicunt??) something either true or false because the things signified by them are true or false or would be if they were formed. And thus it is possible to say that the signified is true which is signifiable through a true proposition and the signified is false which is signified through a false proposition. Again it is able to be said that all true signifiable things are to be called true from the first truth which is God who is the truth and certain judgment of all such things.

To the eighth argument it is said that neither of the aforementioned (predicates), but it is the fact that it is in reality or that it is not. And if it is asked whether this is something, it is said yes, when taking thing loosely for every complex or incomplex signifiable, truly or falsely. And when it is said that there would be a science of contingent things, etc., here it is said no, therefore sciences are about necessary things because their objects are real and necessary things and entities since in this way there is nothing except God. But therefore they are said to be sciences about necessary things which are things which are known to not be able to not to be thus. Consider for example, this knowable thing, every isosceles has three angles, etc., is not said to be necessary because it is necessary that it is isosceles or that it necessarily has three, etc., but because it is necessary that, if it is isosceles, it has three angles, etc. Further this knowable thing is said to be eternal because whenever an isosceles was, it had three, and whenever it should exist, it will always have tree. With respect to the confirmation the consequent would be able to be conceded because we know that the same God exists and we believe the term and we are perhaps able to err about Him by holding some false opinion, and this according to diverse considerations and dispositions.

With respect to another [ninth] argument, the antecedent is denied when speaking about the knowledge of pilgrims, and the proof of this argument it is said that the major premise is false unless it were received self-evidently, that is on account of something asserted that cannot be more certain just as seems to be assumed by Altissiodorensis in the third book of his Summae who says that
the articles of faith are self-evident. Guillelmus Altissiodorensis, xxx . Note the difference concerning something that is self-evident put forward by
Hugolinus in book one, distinction 3, question 1, article 1 Hugolinus de Urbe Veteri, xxx .

With respect to another [tenth] argument, the consequence is denied. For the proof, it is denied that the certitude of faith is infinite, indeed no created certitude is infinite because any such thing is a finite act or habit inclining to a finite act.

With respect to the final argument the major premise is denied because in this case one ought to believe and assert a lie without hesitation, not nevertheless inasmuch as it is a lie, but precisely against the mind of the one saying and thinking the falsity which is actually true.

With respect to the first argument made before the opposition the major premise is conceded and the conclusion which is because the intellect naturally is able to know something. With respect to the confirmation the consequence is denied. For the proof again the consequence is denied. And for the proof this consequence is also denied because the ratio does not move the intellect either equally or in the same mode. On this point see
Henry of Ghent in the first part of the first article 44 14 questions Henricus de Gandavensis, xxx

To another (second) argument, whatever is the case about the antecedent, the consequence is denied, and for the proof it is said that it is true about the complete and precise agent, but the agent intellect is not the total agent causing the understanding, therefore it does not conclude.

To another (third) argument the consequent is conceded, and for the disproof the consequence is denied because in this way it would be proved that the habit of charity or grace is not infused to a creature because not everyone who has the habit perceives it, indeed no one thus, whether in hate or love, is worthy. In the second place it would be able to be said that every
theologian perceives, though they do not perfectly perceive this, nor do they perceive that they perceive.

To the last argument it would be possible to deny the consequence because if it is possible to convince without such a light, nevertheless not in such a way or in a such a perfect mode as faith or theology does, and thus it would be able to say to the immediately preceding (primum praecedens).

In the second place it is possible to deny the antecedent and to be said that helping proofs do not prove because it could be proved in the same way that man from his purely natural ability would be able to achieve beatitude which is false.
